Review: I don't know how we ever got along without Alexa, What I love most is Alexa is not only connected to Amazon's Eco System, she's connected to: Wikipedia this means Alexa is a trivia monster! Alexa is also connected to the General Inter-Net which gives her access to general subjects like news, business, and sports info.
label: Positive

Review: Here is a list of things we use Alexa for, I'm breaking it down between the three categories:
label: Negative

Review: 1.  Amazon Music Alexa will play any song in your Music Library or from Prime Music, that is if you're a Prime Member. The speakers on Alexa are no joke, they can get pretty loud.
label: Negative

Review: 2.  Audible.com if you have any audible books Alexa will gladly read them all you have to do is ask,"Alexa, read my book and she'll do it.
label: Positive

Review: 3. There's a variety of skills you can activate through the Alexa app, anywhere from local news, to games like Simon Says.
label: Positive

Review: 4.  You can ask for jokes, or riddles, and she's full of them, and they're pretty good. Example Joke: Did you hear about the circle that graduated from college?  It got 360 degrees.
label: Positive

Review: 5. You can say Good Morning, and she'll say good morning and then something interesting about that day,
label: Positive

Review: 6. You can turn your home into a smart home by controlling your Nest Thermostat, your lights (you have to update your light switches to the WIFI switches),  all you have to do is go into the Alexa app and search for smart devices.
label: Positive

Review: Everything I hoped for in a digital companion and so much more!  She keeps the lights on and turns them off when needed, reminds me of important events, sets alarms and timers, barks like a guard dog, makes pretty bird sounds, orders 400lbs of butter, tells me to sleep well when I tell her goodnight.
label: Positive

Review: 1. Ask Alexa something trivial, like how old is your favorite celebrity, or what's the tallest building in New York, or the world. She'll not only tell you, she'll look it up for you in the Alexa app so you can read more about it later..
label: Positive

Review: 3. Do you want Alexa to help you spell a word, or define a word, just ask and she'll tell you.
label: Positive

Review: 4. Want to know something about a famous historical figure or event in history, well more times than not she'll know the answer or have it for you in the Alexa app.
label: Positive

Review: 5. Alexa is a wiz at measurements you can ask her how many cups are in a gallon, or how many feet are in a mile, and she'll tell you.
label: Positive

Review: 1. Want to know the score for a sporting event that in progress, or the game results of the last game, Alexa will tell you, just ask Alexa: what's the score of whatever team you follow from baseball, football, basketball, hockey, and she'll even broadcast the March Madness college basketball tournament.
label: Positive

Review: 2. Alexa will tell you the news through NPR or your local news network, all you have to do is set up the skill in the Alexa app for local news, NPR is automatically set up with the echo.
label: Positive

Review: 3. Alexa will tell you stock market news through the set-up of the CNBC skill in the Alexa app.

Now I sending it back... very upset customer right now.

Review: I'm enjoying my Echo.  Although I haven't found any real use for it save the entertainment of being able to talk to it and play music.  The functionality is still VERY limited even with what it can do.  Be forewarned though.  This uses Bing as its back end which beyond awful.  Had I realized that before buying it I may not have purchased it.  The only thing that tipped the scales is that I'm a heavy Amazon Music user and the integration with that was key.  If they can continue to improve on features this will be a great device.  The voice recognition is pretty darn spot on.  Although I could not get it to recognize "Estranged" by "Guns and Roses".

Review: "Alexa, can you make for me medium brew coffee, and do the laundy.." Okay, says Alexa. Just kidding but this product is beyond awesome. It is a game-changer and makes wonder how life used to be before Alexa came along.  I purchased Amazon echo (the big one) and six Echo Dots (4 as gifts to others and 2 for wife's office/our kitchen). I'm planing on adding two additional ones, for my office and home theater. Wife likes it, peace in the house, and here is why: as long as you have Wifi, set up is a breeze. Unlike Siri, Alexa is so intuitive and listening at all times that even a nearby TV show does turn it on. People with accents be damed..Alexa can hear you very well. The Amazon Echo is in my master bedroom: once it was set up, I went into the Skills (under settings) and connected it to my Kasa (smart lighting ).  I have six Kasa bulbs in my bedroom. So here is how awesome Alexa is: when I go to bed,  I just lay down and calmly ask Alexa to play Yo-Yo Ma music from Amazon Prime Account. I turn around and say Alexa, bedroom lights off, and Alexa respond by saying, Okay. Lights off. I ask Alexa to play and turn itself off after say 30 mins - which it does. At 5:00am, Alexa alarm comes on. At the same time, it turns on the Kasa smart bulbs.  When leaving the bedroom, I just say Alexa, bedroom lights off. When we are cooking, my family likes to play trivia games including Jeopardy with EchoDot which is strategically placed in our kitchen. Next task is to connect Alexa to my home theater system. My brother in-law has such a set-up and it is beyond believable, it awesome i.e. Alexa, tell harmony to turn on Netflix and dim the lights.
label: Positive

Review: HUGE HUGE HUGE SECURITY HOLE. ANYONE with a Bluetooth device can connect to this within range. There is NO PIN or any security to prevent someone from connecting to this device. I discovered this when the device reported my neighbor had connected via Bluetooth WITHOUT me doing anything. I was told by "Amazon" that the person connecting "couldn't do anything with it". They pretty much blew me off and opened a "trouble ticket" that went into an Amazon black hole. I'm no expert on Bluetooth, but seems like someone could connect and do malicious stuff with your device. In theory they could order stuff from Amazon Prime, control home automation, open your doors (if you have locks supported by Alexa), and the list goes on and on. What would prevent some "bad guy" from walking by your house, connecting to your device and gathering all kinds of information.

Review: I recieved my Echo as a Valentine's gift from my parents and absolutely love it!!! I'm a pretty tech-mad person and love having my gadgets. I'd been wanting the Echo for awhile, though part of me questioned its usefulness. Well, my parents know me too well and they gifted it to me almost a week ago. Since then, I've found several reasons to love my Echo. One of the most obvious is the music streaming capabilities on it. It's easy to stream from Amazon music or hook it up to my iPhone or iPad to play music or other audio that way. I'm partially blind and will say that the Echo, particularly for its audio and voice capabilities, is an insanely blind-friendly device. The Alexa voice service very seldom fails to understand my commands and I'm always figuring out new tips and tricks. The ability for Alexa to play Kindle and Audible books thrills me as well as I do enjoy a good read when I'm not otherwise caught up in school, family, or video games. If I can get my Echo to read my PDF textbooks then I'll be an even happier camper than I already am. I'm also very excited about my Echo's smart home potential. I look forward to the day I have smart lights and, eventually, even a smart thermostat where I can tell Alexa to change the temperature at a whim rather than squinting at the display of my current thermostat. I'll end this by saying that I love my Echo and can only see myself loving it more as time marches on.
label: Positive

I'm stuck on a crossword puzzle she helps !! kids home work....yep! I need help there too haha. there is no end to her possibilities. I don't currently have any smart switches so I can't comment on those but I wouldn't want to be without my echo

I held off making this purchase for a long time but am now truly glad I made the purchase Echo skills library grows on an almost daily basis and you would be amazed at how many skills I have found while reading articles about other devices it seems that for now Echo just keeps evolving. Review: I use the Echo mostly for playing music. It's a rather expensive toy with a unique skill. It's not great though. I find it exceedingly frustrating when if I have the music playing loudly and ask Alexa to turn down the volume it often does not hear me. I also find it frustrating when I ask Alexa to add something to my shopping list, which she does, but if I say "add onions, sugar and eggs" or something similar she will only add one item onto the list so I must repeat the command several times. I'm not impressed with the knowledge base either. Google Play has the world wide web to pull information from yet Alexa uses Wikipedia and not well, plus you have to be specific with your request or question or you get the pat answer that she doesn't understand the question. Basically I think it's cool, but it's just another gadget that really doesn't do all that much. I would not buy it a second time.

Review: I have been using advanced technology for the last 20 years.  It was born out of necessity not convenience.  My wife passed away 4 years ago leaving me, not only a widow, but a widowed quadriplegic trying to survive on his own.  We were married 20 years and yes she married me when I was already paralyzed.  She was a beautiful lady here on earth and I am sure she is just as beautiful in God's presence.
label: Positive

Review: I have to attest that it has been an arduous journey.  But one thing that has made it possible for me to live on my own even though I am paralyzed from the chest down, is "smart technology."  For example, I am able to run my entire home with apps on my phone, computer or tablet.  I have lights, electric door locks, electric bed, air-conditioning/heat, cameras, both indoor and out side.  Smart technology allows me to input data on my laptop when I am laying in bed - I cannot use my arms when I am laying flat in bed because of the paralysis.  Up to this point, I have used input through joysticks that operate by using my mouth.  They work effectively but the joysticks must be placed specifically in front of my mouth and they have to remain there all night long.  Smart technology allows me to be able to live safely on my own and has even allowed me to help take care of my 75-year-old mother whose health is, due to God's grace and technology, now stable and she is actually helping me more each day.
label: Positive

Review: Alexa has been a blessing beyond my imagination.  She has given me an opportunity that I never thought would be possible.  I still use the joystick input because they are reliable and not subject to Wi-Fi disruption but Alexis is growing more dependable each day.  At this point I have only an echo Dot, but I am ordering, when funds allow, the regular echo and another Dot as well.  To be able to sit it in my electric wheelchair and call out commands without having to struggle with switches or computer input is wonderful.  I have not always been paralyzed.  A car accident left me a quadriplegic 34 years ago.  So, I know what it is to be able to easily walk over and flip a switch or to restart a computer that has locked up.  It is not so easy to do when you are completely paralyzed from your breast line down.  The littlest of things become a struggle.  Alexa will help me to live more independent, live more safely and productive.  I have managed to acquire 2 college degrees, A Bachelors Degree in Social Work and a Masters degree in Public Administration prior to voice input or Bluetooth technology.  And, if I was able to achieve these things prior to the modern "smart technology" I believe that technology such as Alexa will open doors I can only imagine.  I am grateful for this technology and I look forward to a long and beautiful relationship with her!  - Michael
label: Positive

I'm still learning and I'm sure there are some things I won't use Alexa for, such as ordering a pizza (well, maybe I will). I had some difficulty connecting some lights/outlets -- it would be awesome if Alexa could assist with that :). But this is the best thing: I can drive my cat crazy!!! My cat has the habit of cruizing the house in the middle of the night howling at the top of his voice, waking me up. Now I ask Alexa to meow-meow and she does with awesome variety! And my cat comes running and shuts up!

Review: I started using the Amazon Echo in November, and although I like it, Alexa needs some improvements. Here are some comments based on my experience so far:
label: Positive

Review: 1. You have to be very precise when asking Alexa a question. The phrasing is important or she does not understand. For example: when I ask her for a Random Fact, she does not understand until I phrase it, "Alexa, ask Random Fact for a Fact." This would not be so bad if all the requests were phrased the same way, but when you want to find out which holidays are being celebrated daily you must use this phrasing, "Alexa, ask National Day Tracker which holidays are being celebrated today." Other requests require different phrasing which Alexa often claims she does not understand encouraging you to enable the skill which has already been enable.  She also does not quite get what you are asking when using the grocery list app. Instead of mayonnaise, she lists may, or instead of red beans, bens.
label: Positive

Review: 2. Another issue is the music. When I ask for Classical music, Alexa opens with the same exact song each time. If I hear Pachabel's Canon one more time...!! When you ask for Smooth Jazz, get ready to hear Kenny G. The music should be upgraded and songs added on a weekly basis. I am getting ready to switch back to my satellite TV music stations which switch up the music selections more frequently.
label: Positive

Review: 3. Alexa also repeats the same 6 facts when you ask for a Computer Fact, Fruit Fact, Random Fact, Brain fact. Come on: update these facts or get rid of them altogether.
label: Positive

Review: Fun toy and useful tool.  We have a lot of fun with Alexa and the echo.  It gets our music and is handy in the kitchen and the shopping lists and todo lists are handy for the whole family.
label: Positive

Review: Alexa is okay, but she needs some serious upgrades to keep information current. She also needs to be reprogrammed so it is not so painful to ask a question using the exact correct phrasing. The programmers need to stay on top of the apps already listed in the Skills section instead of adding more and more skills that are not well thought out.  Do your homework Amazon: stay on top of things or we will be forced to switch to GOOGLE!!!
label: Positive

Review: I'm enjoying Alexa a lot so far. I've used it for various music options so far, but it has been a lot of fun. It takes some time to find out what you really can do with it. Still experimenting with it.
label: Positive

Review: Basically it's just a fancy bluetooth speaker, for which it is WAY overpriced. The other Alexa features are, quite frankly, underwhelming. Once the novelty of using them wore off after the first weekend, it's become nothing more than a voice activated music player. Which it does quite well. Just don't expect it to do much else very well.

It will play the one song and then stop. I have to tell Alexa every time I want to skip a song and that frustrates me because I can spend several minutes doing this.

Review: My daughter (who recently got an Echo) gave me Amazon credits as a Christmas gift and suggested I get one of these because I could have a lot of fun with it.  So I said, what the heck, I'll try it.  My daughter was right!  It's fun to ask Alexa questions and play games - hands free.  But what I'm really enjoying is the fantastic music and superb sound quality.  I signed up for Music Unlimited, and I can call up any song or album ever produced.  Awesome!  Alexa is also like having a little robot friend to talk to.  I am a senior citizen and live alone.  I think the Echo is a great device for seniors.  You can ask Alexa the same question fifty times and she won't get irritated with you.  LOL.  I think the flat black color is the best.  I waited extra time on delivery, just so I could get it in black.  Looks very cool.

Review: Most common complaints were as follows.
label: Negative

Review: - Power cables failing then the customer being told that it would take something like four weeks to replace the power cable.
label: Negative

Review: - There were also some reports that people wanted to send defective units back for replacement and these individuals were told that they couldn't get a replacement unit, they had to wait for the unit they had purchased to be mailed in, repaired and then sent back to them.
label: Negative

Review: - There were quite a number of reports complaining about connectivity problems, issues with the Internet connection dropping out and causing connectivity issues.
label: Negative

Review: Pursuant to this there were complaints about Customer Service sort of running people around, having them reboot router's, the Alexa unit, and everything else under the sun repeatedly without any real success.

Review: - There was a number of complaints that centered around the microphone on the unit slowly failing over a course of weeks or months.

Instead, no explanation as to the cause of the malfunction, and only an offer to purchase another or a refurbished Echo at around $120. Not interested when I have 2 Dots already. Time to consider other options such as Google Home. Now off to wait for the other two to fail.

In fact, many of the fact-type questions I have asked have not been answered either correctly or at all.  That's fine, except they advertise that it will answer those sorts of questions.

Review: Alexa is a new member of the family and knows all! We are happy with having this around. The voice timers and daily alarms are something that seamlessly makes life easier. When we are cooking, just getting to tell Alexa to set timers instead of stopping and setting them is very efficient. She plays music very well and the speaker is very nice but I just enjoy music and am not a audiophile. I like the feature where you can ask her what the song playing is. We listen to our Amazon Prime music on Alexa and looked up Prime Playlists and keep track of which ones we like on our phones.
label: Positive

Review: Cons: Alexa doesn't register my voice as easily as my husband's which annoys me. If the music is too loud, she has trouble hearing commands and you have to wait for a pause in the music or move close to the speaker. The app interface lets you control the volume, songs, etc directly. You have to say "Alexa" and then pause before the command, and I don't always know if she heard me until I finish the command and she does nothing. (I think there's a way to get her to "ding" when she hears you.) Wish she'd say "yes?"  Maybe it's just me, though. All in all, we couldn't do without her. We missed her while on vacation and had to look at the clock for the time, set alarms, look up the weather on our own. Haha, just kidding (sort of)

I keep my Echo in my kitchen, and the ability to ask Alexa to read news, or play a particular genre of music is pretty cool.  While I don't find myself using my Echo all that much, it is certainly a great addition to anybody's home, and a product that I would certainly recommend to others.  In my opinion, Amazon has done a great job with their products, and Echo is no exception.  An impressive device, highly recommended!

Review: Five Stars with a caveat, this will not be a true GREAT device until you don't have to mention the app you want to use.  I want every response to be seamless. "Alexa what sound does a blue jay make?"  Not "Alexa open (add app name) what sound does a blue jay make. Because I can't remember the blasted app name. With a screen you can see the app, and use it. With Alexa I have to remember that app name.  I want everything to work as well as the grocery list, generic and easy.  Yes I am picky and want Alexa to be like Rosie from the Jetsons.  I want total integration of what I need without saying the app. Alexa should know what apps I have installed and use them, WITHOUT prompting.  Come on Amazon you never heard Cpt. Kirk saying 'Computer Open comm unit and contact Scotty.'  Kirk had no stinking apps before his commands and I don't want any either. So Amazon Alexa team of brainiacs please get fixing this issue ASAP, I am 52 and need this before I get much older. Plus I really need my flying car that I was promised at five via the Jetson infomercial.
label: Positive

Review: On a serious note Alexa does understand both my husband and son while they pause mid sentence, where her friend Siri does not. Alexa just keeps listening like a good friend, while they pause for dramatic effect. My husband has a lisp, that is not present unless tired, thanks to years of speech therapy as a kid. Alexa does understand him even when he lisps. She also understand when he ends a sentence with a preposition. So she gets five stars for language.

I see great potential here and our kid really likes talking to it, We have an African Grey Parrot so were interested to see what happens. The Insteon with the ISY Portal works good and makes it easy to control equipment since you are not limited to buttons on a remote, Blue Iris worked good and I was able to connect it after several tries

Review: The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars for now is that the Bluetooth only connects devices to the Echo and you can not connect BT Speakers to it like the Dot (Gen 2), You can only use 1 Harmony Hub so if you want to control more than one tv in a different room you need to buy something else, I am waiting for AnyMote Ir blaster to come in and im hoping that might give me more options but if not I can control 2 TV's in 2 rooms using both devices this way, . If the skills allow more integrations later like calling/texting people using trusted services or linking cell phones , Intercom between devices, the Alexa app on ph also doubles as an Alexa device to be used when mobile not just setting up the Echo and Dot skills, other manufactures make accessories that work better so I can get BT or Wifi speakers etc that can be cut on using Skills and not using automation devices or leaving speakers on to make more convenient  Also note you have to upgrade your Prime Music or purchase the individual music plan to be able to stream any music to all amazon devices (dots, Echo's etc using amazon services, Right now I use Spotify for me and the amazon service for family. That would be my wish list but out of the box it is still worth getting and the price is reasonable.

Review: Just picked this up over the weekend with a few Philips Hue bulbs and starter kit.  It was pretty easy to set up (connected to my 5G wifi) and get everything up and running.  I also have a Logitech Harmony Elite universal remote which is connected as well.  I created rooms with the hue app and then groups under the Alexa app, so now when I walk into my apartment all I have to say is "Alexa, turn home on" and it will turn on my living room lights as well as my TV.  It is very responsive and can hear me from pretty much any room; apartment is just under 1,000ft (if you live in a bigger residence then you may need to get some additional echos).  It has had a problem understanding me a few times, you just have to make sure you are speaking clearly as I kind of mumbled the command.  So far I have been very happy with the purchase, now I'm going to look into IFTTT.com and see what else I can do with the Amazon Echo to turn my place into more of a smart home.  I'd get the Nest thermostat and front door locks but not worth it since I'm in an apartment and I don't think they'd like me messing with the wiring and changing the locks.  I would recommend this product.

Review: Purchased this solely to play music from my personal library stored on Amazon Music.  I have no interest in ordering a pizza or turning lights on and off, I just want to hear MY music.  Alexa is totally unable to deal with this.  I ask to play something in a given genre from my library and she gives me a radio station instead, or just as likely, gives absolutely no response whatsoever.  So I am reduced to using the third rate Alexa app to get what I want.  Not even remotely what I expected from this device.  Sound quality is excellent, but Alexa is dumber than a box of rocks.  And the light ring is quite annoying, particularly when the mic is muted and it turns red and is bright enough to light up a room.  Should be a way to dim that or turn it off.  And for the price Amazon could spend 5 cents to include some written documentation instead of forcing you to log in and search around to find the device FAQs which MIGHT be able to answer a question or two.  Since I have to use my phone to control Echo I would be better off just using one of those small Bluetooth speakers or just connecting to my main stereo by Bluetooth. Disappointed, to say the least.

On the contrary, the process of reconnecting shows that Amazon has listened to well-worn computer 'experts' without listening to its customers. After all, we are not all computer professionals, and we don't repeat the same steps for problems on a regular basis, like pros do. If I could I would return the Echo, even though I like it very much when it's working. For $200 they should include easy set-up, as in most tablets and laptops nowadays.

Review: I received this as a gift, so the only resource I had to commit to it was a wall outlet. And I still don't think it was worth it. It has some ok features, like telling you the weather and sort-of telling you some facts. It is a good speaker for bluetooth (I guess-- I don't have much to compare it to). It is frankly annoying in so many ways, however. It doesn't understand most of what you ask it, even when you're asking something that is within its capabilities. This is an early-gen problem for software: the user has to learn the acceptable commands in the software's limited vocabulary and only use that formula. A truly smart device would learn the ways its users like to give inputs and adapt to it. This thing doesn't seem to be able to do that. At least not /yet/. But this isn't my major complaint with it. My major complaint is that there is just no way to actually TRUST the information it gives us is accurate, or exhaustive, or the best (according to any standard). How do I know the "pizza place" I asked it to search for isn't one that paid to be the top result? Do you trust Amazon to objectively provide you with what you're looking for, or do you think Amazon may be monetizing your needs and wants by filtering and sorting what it presents to you according to its own agenda? That question will need to be answered with confidence before I want a listening device made by a retail sales company in my living room.
label: Positive

Review: Turns out the Echo is a pretty good blue tooth speaker, can play songs on demand, is handy as a timer and for measurement conversion, answers a few questions, but is otherwise pretty stupid, meaning it  just doesn't know a whole lot.  I thought I would be able to simply ask a question and I would get the answer. Mostly the answer is, I can't find the answer to that question.  We're talking pretty uncomplicated questions: i.e. What's the closest star and what is the recommended refrigerator temperature.  Back to google.  Guess I expected  too much.  I do enjoy the Eco, except when I am yelling at Alexa for repeatedly saying, Ummm, I don't know what you mean by that question.

Review: First of all as a product its features are not as robust as Google Home currently.  I don't think they will ever be.  Consider this as a bonus item to tie in your amazon products and services.  I use google home for my home automation mostly, but I have an Alexa in my bedroom to take care of the home automation in my personal area.  Alexa easily accesses my kindle library to read my purchases to me directly next to my bed.  So this would be a small advantage the Echo system has over google.  As far as hardware goes, it's similar enough to the Google Home.  I think Google Home wins on the low end side compared to Alexa at full volume.  Alexa does sound a little more crisp in the high end.  Ultimately, personal preference really.  I own and use both Alexa and Google Home for different things.  They compliment each other so nicely.

Why pay more when you can stream pandora through the Echo for free? The speakers are good but I also could have plugged in my laptop as background music. If you plan on using it with a home kit (lights, locks, etc) I'm sure it would be great but not really worth it for anything less than that. I guess for the money we spent on this, we were expecting a little bit more than a glorified speaker.

They do not tell you this when you read the information  about the Echo.  Be aware!

Review: Love it! Wish it was as smart as Google Home as far as asking questions about things. She will do that with the right apps but Alexa does more for me than Google would overall. Love the speakers. She reads my Kindle books to me when I'm ironing and working in the laundry room. Love my weather and news briefings. Love that she can give me a what's up on my google calendar. She plays my Pandora for free. And will play music on a whim when asked. She'll order something for me which allows a code to be set up that you give so a child or guest won't leave you with a surprise order! lol She responds to Good Morning with an interesting response. She is a good friend now! You can set up IFTTT app to integrate other apps and deeds for her! And...it was easy other than the google calendar thing. She only seems to recognize google entered apps and nothing layered in from other calendars, like outlook. So I've not been able to integrate work but I have my phone for that so that's ok. I've not turned our home into a smart house yet but she could turn on and off anything electrical with a purchase of a device that talks to internet. Love it!!! Now I want the DOT for the back part of the house! lol

Review: To be fair, Alexa isn't perfect.  There is a learning curve on how to phrase things to get the answer you want.  For example, if you ask "What time does the University of Michigan play basketball today?" she'll tell you she doesn't know.  But if you say "What time is the Michigan Wolverines basketball game?" she'll say "The Michigan Wolverines play Ohio State University at 7pm".  I've found phrasing to be important with many questions I ask, but especially with sports questions.  Sometimes it takes a few tries but you can usually get the answer you want.

Review: Works nicely.  The volume and sound clarity is good.  And the white looks good.  It actually forces you to THINK before you ask a question, i.e, your language has to make sense. It only answers questions with definitive answers, i.e., no opinions or predictions (to my knowledge).  I was interested in the music component, but it appears you have to subscribe to Amazon's music library to enjoy that feature.  I use it mostly to give me the top news of the day and answer definitive questions. I'm sure it will become more useful as I link it to different services and devices that I have.  Like most tech items, the more you put into it, the more you'll get out of it.  All in all, a nice product.

Review: I signed up for Amazon Music Unlimited for access to a larger library of classical music.  But, even when an album is listed as available for play on the Echo under the Unlimited plan, Alexa has -- more often than not -- been unable to recognize the titles. Moreover, there is currently no way to create a playlist on the app or website for these supposedly streamable albums with a simplified name that Alexa might recognize (which is what I do with the classical music in the My Library).  At the end of the day, even though there are, for example, a number of editions of Mozart's Die Entfhrung aus dem Serail listed as available for streaming on Echo under that Amazon Music Unlimited plan, the only response I received from Alexa so far is "I cant' find...." over and over.  To be fair, Alexa has no problem with requests like "play songs by Pink," or "play solo classical piano music."  But, I've had virtually no success with getting it to play specific classical titles  I'm canceling Music Unlimited and keeping my fingers crossed that they will improve the search capability in the app at some point so that streaming classical music with longer, complex titles is possible .

Review: This has been AMAZING for my husband, who is disabled. I still work full-time and he is alone for most of the day. He typically watches a lot of tv, but since I bought the Echo (Alexa!), he has begun to enjoy playing songs from when we were young. I purchased Amazon Music Unlimited, since some of the artists and songs he likes are not available on the free version of Spotify (and the paid version of Spotify is more expensive than Amazon Music). Even better for his mental acuity, he's now hooked on playing sports trivia and especially baseball trivia. There are MANY baseball trivia apps (and football trivia, hockey trivia, etc)  and I think I've enabled all of them. I made him a list of phrases that Alexa will respond to, in order to open the different apps. He also likes to play the animal game occasionally and 20 Questions.

Review: The echo is pretty darn neat, at least I thought so until I tried it.  I guess if you're into mainstream pop music and the rest of the general crap you find on the radio then Echo will be perfect for you.  If you like music that isn't so mainstream, in my case power metal and djent, then you're pretty much screwed if you want to use most of Echo's functions.  I have to physically start playing a playlist or album on my phone and have Echo play that just like any other bluetooth speaker can (but for a whole hell of a lot less money), but for the oldies on said phone, it works fine.  So basically the Echo?  So not metal.

Review: Had a little problem with may ECHO and had to contact Customer Service!  From day one ALEXA would not respond to any request without pressing the button on top!  However, it would respond to friends speaking to it over the phone and YouTube videos on how to operate ECHO!  Customer Service checked out ECHO remotely and gave her a clean bill of health!  They then asked me to move the ECHO closer to my router and it began working as normal!  Turns out I had it plugged into an surge protector/outlet that was on the same electrical circuit as a microwave, television, DVD Player, and a Sound Bar!  The operation of the microwave was affecting the ECHO even when the the ECHO was not in use!

Review: Wow Amazon, I am so disappointed.  I bought an Echo to compare to a recently-purchased Google Home.  The Home's setup took literally less than 2 minutes and went flawlessly.  The Echo wouldn't set up, the app kept going back to the connection screen.  After far too much time exploring answers on Google I got it connected before opening the app.  So the Echo responded to Alexa and worked as expected, but the iOS app on my iPhone and iPad keeps going back to the "Begin Setup" screens and loops through that over and over.  I finally called Amazon and was told that their Alexa app doesn't work with the new version of iOS released a week and half ago.  I tried to go to alexa.amazon.com on both Safari and Chrome and get the same screen as the app.

Review: An interesting audio playback device with some ginger bread tossed on top that can do some basic work like updating calendars, but before you buy one you should know that this isn't the computer on the Starship Enterprise.  It has no idea what the barometric pressure at the nearest NWS office is, it can't tell you traffic conditions until you manually type an address into the phone app, and even occasionally has issues finding music in your Prime Music account.  The sound coming from it is crystal clear and it will do a few cute things like finish movie lines for you but this has a long way to go to be truly useful.  Hopefully the folks behind the cloud will eventually allow the product to grow in utility.  Right now I am not sure its worth the price.

Review: First of all, beware that you get a free trial for Amazon digital music with the purchase. If you don't cancel it within 30-days, you will be charged a monthly fee of $4.32. I never received the warning email about this, so it automatically appeared on my credit card and then I cancelled the subscription.  Also, be aware that this device is always listening. So if you are sensitive about hackers getting into to your WiFi, this is another vulnerability. It's kind of creepy if you think about it.  It's not yet compatible with the new Savant Remote, so I was misguided in buying this in the first place.  If it wasn't too late, I'd return it.  Once I got beyond the initial newness of it, it now just sits there unused for the most part.  So it's a waste of money in my household to be honest.

Review: The Echo is a fun and interesting little gadget. Paired with other items like the Philips Hue system it becomes a cool little command center for your home. But, the products inability to pair with a bluetooth speaker is shocking. So what if it already has a speaker in it? Set it up so when it is paired with a different speaker you can choose which one to use. With all the things the Echo can do it blows my mind that it cannot connect to my Bose speaker. If I had known this was going to be the case I would have paid half as much for a Dot and saved myself the disappointment. Will likely return for a Dot after having waited more than a month to receive the this product as a gift for Christmas.

Review: I should have read the reviews before buying.  I bought the Amazon Echo and couldn't get it to answer any questions except the ones suggested by Amazon.  It hasn't answered more than a couple of questions I've asked it.  After this failure, I bought a Google Home (the big competitor to Echo) and it is infinitely better.  You can ask Google Home random questions using your natural voice and syntax and get an answer about half the time.  For example, Echo can't tell you who the members of a band or the cast of move/TV show are, but Google Home can.  Unless you subscribe to a service like Amazon Music, Echo can only play a shuffle of fifteen second clips of Beatles music, but Google Home goes to Pandora (no extra subscription required) and plays their full length songs.  You will enjoy the Google Home much more than the Echo.

Review: Amazon did a fantastic job of creating this tubular info-taining command center! There are so many cool and awesome things its able to do that I'll hit the highlights that work for our household. First, we love that it follows your voice in the room (the circle lighting will show which direction it is 'listening'), the speaker is wonderfully balanced, so whether listening to music, the news or to Alexa speaking, I have nothing but high marks for its sound quality, given its size. Next, set up (after downloading the app to our iPhones) was quick, easy and very intuitive. The more you look over the app, the more you will realize a world of 'skills' (as Amazon refers to them - we've nicked named them "echolettes" LOL) that the unit is able to perform once they are turned on and you master the right sequence of keywords to initialize them. We've added things to shopping lists, while asking about the weather and our calendar of events and then asked Alexa to change the temp of our Nest thermostats in various parts of the house, simply by saying her name and then our commands, sometimes sitting in the living room or simply pass through - she is always there listening and ready. We've ordered some LED programmable lights and I can hardly wait for Alexa to help set the mood in the house, room to room, all from a simple voice request

Review: I bought to play with.  I really wasn't expecting much, but the Echo was on sale at the time, and I was curious to see what it could do.  And I am really glad I bought it.  It arrives nicely packaged.  Setup was extremely easy.  You do have to download the Alexa app, though, to do so because the app is what enables you to configure the Echo and make use of some of its features.  So you will need to have a smart phone or tablet.  Once set up, though, the Echo works great.
label: Positive

Review: When you first set up Echo there is a list of words you have to speak so it can learn your voice and inflection.  This takes only a minute or so.  After doing so it does an amazing job of recognizing speech commands.  When I have spoken clearly it has yet to miss a command.  The only mistakes it has made was when I accidentally misspoke.  I don't have a thick accent, though, so others who do may have a different experience.
label: Positive

Review: It is fun to ask Alexa what time it is, what the weather forecast is, and what the current news updates are.  You can ask Alexa to sound an alarm at a specific time.  But what I especially like is the ability to ask Alexa to create shopping and to do lists for you which are then readily accessible via the Alexa app on your phone or tablet.  In the past I used to keep a written grocery shopping list that often would be forgotten when I went shopping.  Not any more.  Since my phone is always with me I have the shopping list with me, too.  You can check off items as you gather them in the store, and the app will automatically delete them from your list.  The only thing I don't like is Alexa orders the items in serial fashion as you add them.  There is no way to shuffle the list so items in the same category can be clustered together.  It's a minor annoyance that makes grocery shopping with a long list less efficient.
label: Positive

Review: The sound quality is pretty good for a Bluetooth speaker.  Music sounds rich with sufficient bass that it does not sound tinny like other speakers.  It can play music pretty loudly, and you can adjust the volume just by asking Alexa to turn it up or down.  You can ask Alexa to play music from your collection on Amazon's music server.  You can ask Alexa to play any type of music, though, and if it is not part of your collection it will stream music from a free service much like a radio station (but with no commercials).
label: Positive

Review: The range for Echo is somewhat limited.  I have it set up in a small apartment right now, and I find it will not work if you are in another room even if the door is open.  So you will want to put it in a central location where you think you will use it the most.

But I anticipate I will do so at some point in the future.

Review: I think the Echo is a great idea which will revolutionize the way we do things. However, at this time, the product needs time to grow and expand it's capabilities. For example... When I ask Alexa for the weather I get the complete forecast which is good. That said, Alexa does not know how to respond to, "What is the wind speed?" Important for me as I fly drones. Asking her for the temperature or rain ( I forget which) the answer was the complete forecast all over again. Sorry, If I want to hear the complete forecast I'll ask for it. If I want only one specific weather item and ask for that item I don't need to hear the complete forecast. Besides which she never gave me the wind speed either generally or specifically. Another example was when I gave a song a "thumbs up" Alexa replied "You can only give a thumbs up to a custom radio station". When I asked Alexa "What is a customized radio station", she could not answer. Also, she could not play any music off my desktop, except after I uploaded to the cloud. Which meant music on my desktop inches away from me had to be streamed in from who knows where.  My Echo experience was interesting, but, at this time, the Echo seems like a toy to me... but give it time...  For now I have returned the Echo and Dot.

I'm heavily on the novelty side now.

Review: So far the Echo is working fairly well.  After almost a month, I'm still discovering what I can do with it.  I love the Shopping and To Do lists, although I wish I could create multiple lists in each category.  I understand I can add such a skill, but I don't want to use an additional app on my phone for that. My biggest complain about the Echo is that it doesn't seem to understand natural language very well. Whenever I ask her a questions for which the answers could easily be found in any search engine, she comes back with something to the effect that "I did not understand your question."  Maybe it's the way I'm asking it.  I have added a few skills (e.g., Fitbit, Bloomberg, NPR, etc.). The skills works well.

And even if you assumed they said something that sounded like whatever that content was, there is no way to keep that from playing. You cannot prohibit explicit content for any reason. The rep finally admitted the device not for kids. Should I just get rid of them so I can enjoy my Echo?  Anyway, I turned it off and will likely return or give to someone without kids.

Review: I'm going to sound negative but I am not negative on the Echo (I have the Echo and just ordered a Dot plus a speaker).  In this review I am going to try to set expectations for any new user.  There are two reasons I wanted a voice operated device: play music and eventually control electrical devices (smart home).  I looked at Google Home and Echo and settled on the Echo because I am an Amazon Prime member and I did not want to pay for another music service like I would have using Google Home. Regarding the second use, we are the early stage of the VHS vs. Betamax like war with these voice controlled devices.  What you need to understand is that most smart hardware control has to be through a "hub" that is part of the controlled device product line or a semi (because there is no universal) universal hub like the Samsung SmartHub or Wink Hub (or other hubs) which talk to some/many but not all smart devices. Echo given its head start appears to be in the lead in the hardware compatibility for now.  The right solution is to build the hub capability into Echo and cut out the middle man hub.  That will take some time just like the Betamax/VHS wars did and the price point of the Echo will go up.
label: Positive

Review: If you just want sound to fill a room, then Echo is great. It certainly would not satisfy an audiophile but it does the job nicely and my wife is very happy (!).  You can always attach (wire or Bluetooth) a speaker, but really if you are just looking for background music, the Echo by itself is good enough. My Echo sits on a ledge between the kitchen and living room and easily puts out enough sound at Level 5 to cover 1000 sqft in our open ground floor. I will say that the volume control (which can be voice controlled or manually) is not very linear.  Below level 4 the sound drops off very sharply so Level 4 or above is needed for better sound quality. Still if you buy a Dot, an Anker portable speaker (very good ratings) and USB charger, it will cost about $110 compared to a $199 Sonos Play1 which has to have a tablet or smartphone to drive it and doesn't do anything but play music.  The Dot/Speaker combination is a winning combination for me because it can do so much more.
label: Positive

Review: There is a lot of hype about the Alexa "Skills." Remember in the early days of Google Play what the android apps looked like and did?  Essentially that is what the Skills are today. They are pretty much data bases providing some information on a specific topic and masquerading as an "intelligent" app. Very few add any real intelligence and most are not rated very high.  Since they are mostly free, you get what you pay for.
label: Positive

Review: So as I said this may sound negative, but I am not negative on the Echo environment. For now, it is doing what I needed (room filling music) and has some useful everyday features that are helpful (calendar, lists, news, weather and internet radio).  I've rated it 4 stars taking 0.5 off for the non-linear volume and another 0.5 for inability to play music on selected or all devices.  The latter is something I think will be fixed as it matures and the former may or not be correctable at this price point. So take the plunge, get your feet wet and see how it fits into your life.  If you are an Amazon Prime member, this is a great way to access your music library.

If you are more serious about music then neither speaker will suffice and you will need to connect a Dot to an amplifier with stereo speakers or other speaker solution. Still only going to get steaming quality output either way.

Review: We like our Echo, but I don't think we're using "her" to full advantage. I definitely ask her the weather every morning and use her "timer" feature for cooking and doing the laundry. My husband has asked her how to spell things and we tried asking her to play music, but that's where it got confusing, The only way I can get her to play "my" music is by going on my phone to the Alexa App, and choosing music there, and then the music on the Echo will start to play. But if I asked the Echo "Alexa - play some Christmas music", she answered "I'm sorry, I can't seem to find any Christmas music", even though I had added Christmas music to my Amazon Prime music list. So I'm not clear on how the music feature is supposed to work.  I still haven't taken the time to have her play games with me. My husband has asked her for game scores, though. And we don't have any "smart" appliances, so we can't taken advantage of that feature. So right now, she's kind of an expensive weather report & timer.

If it were really good at playing music I may have given it three stars but it is not. A lot of songs you would want to listen to are not available for free and because echo works off bing and not google, it can't play youtube audio content. The device often interrupts you when you're trying to request a song and says "here's a station you might like" and just like a used car salesperson it offers something that indeed you would not like - for example; dora the explorrer songs..? wtf?

Review: I bought this shortly before Christmas and it's taking me some time to get used to using it. It's not natural to talk to the Echo but once you get the hang of it, it's fun and it's so very useful. I now have this *and* a dot and am considering a second dot for the kitchen. I use the echo to update my grocery list (Alexa, add milk to my shopping list) -- this is by far, my most used skill. I also use the dot in the bedroom to wake me in the morning (Alexa, set alarm for 4:45am) and with a subtle pulsing light and light music, it wakes me every morning. It provides me with the morning 'flash' a run-down of curated headlines from my local news, NPR, fox sports and the WSJ. We enjoy playing jeopardy with the Echo and Alexa has a sense of humor. After hearing me say "Alexa, add this to the shopping list, Alexa add that to the shopping list" my husband asked "Alexa kiss my butt" and guess what...she responded :) If you are a Prime member, it will play tons of music too. I've been having a blast with this and am looking forward to adding an Echo enabled outlet to control lamps while I am away.

If it's in your budget I recommend getting an Echo Dot along with a Bose SoundTouch 30 or SoundTouch 20 (the SoundTouch 10 isn't that great).

Review: It's super nice to ask and get the weather, play games, listen to music, get some headlines, stuff like that. I haven't tried the order part yet, because I like to see a picture of the thing I am buying to verify it's what I want. Alexa is not so good at searching to find an answer, when I ask questions like "How many times have the New England Patriots football team have gone to the Super bowl? For questions like this, I get "I don't know the answer". If I use the wikipedia command, she starts reading the page. I have to prompt her to read more. It can take a while to get my answer. I would like Alexa to search to find the answer when I ask it the first time, versus read the first sentence of a wikipedia page, then ask if I want her to read more. So, the search technology from spoken language needs to get a lot better, and I am sure they are working on it. Otherwise, it's fun to play around with and offer's lots of games, and interfaces to other appliances.

Review: Echo is a game changer.  I like being able to add stuff to my grocery list, and have it link to the list on my phone. I can ask what the weather will be like, order Amazon items,just by asking. I can ask for a playlist, say, for dinner music, or studying, or sync it to my home stereo. The sound is decent, and I find that Echo does a good job of "hearing" me when I ask a question.  She understands my kids too, which can actually be a problem. Echo doesn't discern between enquirers. Review: I pre-ordered mine when they were $99 and never looked back.  Technology fascinates me to no end and yes I'm "that guy" that has to have the latest and greatest.  Neither bragging nor complaining but that's just the way it is.  My #1 priority with electronics is that they be "plug-n-play" and Echo certainly meets that priority easily.  Out of the box, plug it in, and start asking questions.  No joke it is that simple.  Everybody loves to ask questions and it really surprises me that a lot of people are not even aware this is available. Really not much I can add that is not repetitious other than it has been all I dreamt it would be and so much more.  I also purchased the Dot for my bedroom and other than speaker size there is really no difference. One more observation is that I am amazed at how many people are freaked out that "it is always listening."
label: Positive

Review: I really enjoy Alexa, especially for music. Amazon offers a great music deal for Alexa and I would highly recommend it. I can play whole albums, tracts, artists, genres and even mood music. I have found if I go to Amazon digital music, you can find almost any album you want Alexa to play. She seems to have a bit trouble with classical music, but it isn't a deal killer. Some of the skills are fantastic. If you are a fan of old radio, there are many programs, Supeman, Dragnet, Gunsmoke and even the suspense thrillers. I do agree with a lot of reviews that say Alexa is not as informative as Sari or Google, there are many things she cannot find. The calendar and weather integration is super. I am very pleased with my purchase and would recommend this to anyone.
label: Positive

Review: Alexa is a lot of fun and very smart!  She was our New Year's Eve DJ!

Review: Love it!!!!!!  Keep in kitchen use it for music. Just tell Alexa what I want to hear and she plays it.  Blasts it if I want and lowers it when I want.  No more running to my phone to google something.  I just ask Alexa.  I feel like I have someone in the kitchen with me.
label: Positive

Review: The Amazon Echo has come a long way. I was one of the first people to order this and had to wait a few months for it to arrive. At first, I'm not sure anyone knew what to do with it. I suffer from a speaking disorder, as a result of being hit head-on by a distracted driver while riding my motorcycle. August 19, 2014. I tell you this because at first I wasn't understood by my own Echo.  I still am taking speech therapy for my disorder, however now I can speak to Alexa and she typically understands me well.  It has taken 1 year to accomplish this. Now I control my echos (yes, I have  one on each floor of my house, one hooked up to my stereo to broadcast through my home, and if I'm in a different room, I use the remote control to speak with her. Today, I look at the functionality and it is incredible. I just learned how to get Echo to be a MARS fact finder, and listen to Digital stations. I already learned how to use my Pandora radio. I haven't got Alexa to turn on/off lights, but soon. Amazon programmers have made Alexa incredible. Everyone should have Echo in their home !!!
label: Positive

Review: I love it - just wish I knew that it always had to be plugged in.  I wasn't aware.

Review: DO NOT RELY ON THE ECHO'S ALARM!!!  I have had the Echo for almost a year.  Overall I like it. I use it as my wake up alarm every morning.  USUALLY, it works, but not always.  Three times since I got it I have set the alarm for the following morning and it simply failed to go off.  Each time this happened, the Echo had acknowledged back to me that my alarm was set for the requested time. And for each of the three times the alarm failed to work, I have not been able to figure out what went wrong.  The device's alarm function is simply UNRELIABLE. If you are going to use the Echo to set an alarm, make sure you have a backup alarm set as well.  The alarm feature, which should be rock solid, is instead very disappointing, and two out of the three times it did not go off for me, caused me to be late for work.

Review: I really, REALLY wanted to love this. I purchased it on QVC because they offered a better deal. Unfortunately more than half the things Alexa is supposed to do, she does not. She cannot answer most of my questions. If I have skills enabled, and say one of the prompts advertised for that skill, she never understandable. I ALWAY  have to first ask her to open a certain skill to get her to let me use that skill, eliminating the hands free option, since I can't remember all the skill names. She claims to be a jukebox bit this feature has never worked for me. I  have music unlimited but when I ask her to play certain songs she either plays samples or can't find it. Again eliminating the hands free feature, because I have to go into the app to play the music. This is currently what I use her for mostly. To me the basics and she just won't do these things. Now she collects dust because most things I need her for she can't do. So far the best working feature is asking the forecast. I have had her for a few months and it has not gotten better.  I really wanted this to work...My husband wants to sell her because I essentially paid $150 for a speaker and to get the weather.

Review: Oh my gosh I just love this thing!!  A relative insisted I needed one, but it sounded like an expensive gadget that I probably didn't need.  My curiosity increased as I kept hearing more people talk, but I still didn't "get" it.  It was just a coincidence that I was shopping for a wireless speaker during this time.  I looked at the Echo reviews from the standpoint of a wireless speaker, and while not the best, they were solidly good.  It was also significantly cheaper than the speakers I had bern looking at, so I decided why not?  I could have a fun little gadget at the same time!  I have to say that this "gadget" changed my life the very first day.  The sound is great, I can ask for any random song or sing genre and it will find and play.  I can call across the room to ask it to be louder or softer, or stop.  It tells me jokes, the time, the weather, answers random truvia queries, and enters on-the-spot items on my shopping and "to do" lists.  "Siri" and voice commands on my iPhone translate incorrectly ALL of the time.  Alexa has only mis-heard me twice so far, I talk to "her" all of the time, and the mistake was totally understandable.  She even tells me she's glad I'm home, if I ask if she missed me (I live alone) <f0><U+009F><U+0098><U+0082><f0><U+009F><U+0098><U+0082>

One of which is a cat meowing sound....I have 2 cats who are highly territorial and i enjoy messing with them from time to time.  Typically I use a application on my smartphone to make fake cats meow, and they come running over to me concerned that their favorite spot on my lap will soon be lost.  I get two cats who are extra lovey, warm, and purring to cuddle with and we all win.

Review: My cats are in door cats, and sometimes they like to ....try to escape out the front door.  My echo is in the kitchen on the opposite side of the house as the front door....I uploaded the cat meowing app, used the voice command to start it - the cats were instantly distracted and I was able to cart all of the groceries and items from my car into the house with out closing the front door, or even having to lock up the cats. I estimate that if used on an occasional bases, I have 5 mins where I can have the front door open and the cats will be thoroughly distracted.  First Win.

Review: I debated for months, although I badly wanted to add Alexa to our household. After missing a few great sales, I finally caught the Echo at a special price and jumped. Alexa makes my life easier in all the ways I expected. Her shopping and to-do list features are probably two of the most utilized by me, because I'm a huge fan of making lists. My seven year old daughter loves games like The Magic Door, often exclaiming "It's SO realistic!" as she and Alexa head off on another adventure. The fifteen year old in the house likes to have Alexa surprise me with random songs he wants me to hear, so it's been fun bonding over and expanding our eclectic musical interests. My parents, both in their 70's, were a bit confused the first time they heard "Alexa, turn it down", wanting to know who in the world Alexa is, but they've gotten used to me blurting out seemingly random conversations with an invisible assistant. All in all, we love Alexa. I've actually added a Dot in my bedroom and my son's as well, so now she can properly manage every corner of our home. My husband worries she might get a little "too smart", but we expect to wipe that thought from his mind soon ... right, Alexa?

Review: I waited a long time to buy myself this Christmas present (Merry Christmas to ME!) and I have to say, in the month and a half we have had it we are having a lot of fun with Alexa and also finding her useful and easy to use. I think anyone would enjoy and use this item. I did go back and forth a bit between purchasing this platform or Google Home (largely because we are Android/Google users) but in the end I chose Alexa because of the sale ($139 at Christmas) and I'm such a huge Amazon Prime user, it just makes sense. I haven't yet used it to order or re-order product (I'm such a stickler for price and other details, I want to see that before I "hit send") but we are enjoying trying out the new Amazon Music Unlimited App and also getting weather updates on command. I love telling Alexa to play my favorite songs, rather than wait and hope they come around on some station. I will warn you, if you plan to watch Youtube instructional videos with tips on using Alexa, do so BEFORE you plug her in! She has incredibly sensitive hearing and kept doing everything she heard the videos mentioning (to the point where I finally decided to unplug her and restart the process later). I also have had one really funny experience to-date. It was a rainy, gloomy day and I was in the mood for something mellow to play in the background while I started my day. I couldn't remember the name of the artist  but there is a woman who plays cello music that my husband and I LOVE. I asked for "Cello Music" but Alexa wants an artist's name or song name (or line from the song) so I tried the only name that popped in my head: I said, "Alexa, play Yo Yo Ma". She retorted something like: "in order to access Yo Ma Jo you must first download the Yo Ma Jo app." So, I said, "Okay. Alexa, download 'Yo Ma Jo' App" all the while wondering what the 'Jo' was about. Immediately Alexa asked if I wanted to access 'Yo Ma Jo' App. I said "sure". She said: "Yo Mama BUTT CHEEKS are SO big, not even Moses could part them". Then, "would you like to hear another?" I almost fell off my chair when I realized I had downloaded the "Yo Mama Joke" App! . But I went ahead and listened to another good 3 minutes of "Yo Mama" jokes and had a good laugh! Get Alexa; you won't regret this purchase! At some point I will also purchase Google Home and I'll come back to do a comparison.

Review: My sister-in-law had an Echo back in beta and loved it and promoted it to the max. I was blown away the first time it showed off with tremendous sound quality and Siri like capabilities. This Christmas she gave several as gifts and I've been using it at its most basic capacity. The alarm feature is wonderful and in fact I selected the Ferris Bueler wake up call as my preset alarm tone. I guaranty this is the most effective wake up alarm I have ever had and it shocks me awake to the point of not even considering snooze or going back to sleep. I've scratched the serface in what it can do beyond being a remarkable speaker platform with countless channeled and capabilities. My only complaint is that I play it at volume level 10 and although it boasts that it can still hear commands even through this volume of music I wind up screaming at her to change the channel or turn down the volume. I am excited to expand my base of knowledge and try some of the  peripheral devices to control lights and switches. It's to large to take as a travel companion and this is what now leads me to consider the Tap as my go-to blue tooth travel mate. With impressive sound quality and 9 hrs of charge range it may replace several of my blue tooth travel speaker wannabes. Over all you can't go wrong with this impressive Amazon product.  Amazon never ceases to amaze me.

Review: The Amazon Echo is a great product for the entire household. The Echo platform is a great platform to use and is very user friendly. I give this product three stars for a couple reasons. The first is price. The echo Dot blows the echo out of the water in comparison to price. You can get the same thing minus the speaker for a third of the price. Yes the speaker is far better then the dot but the option for an external speaker is a feature that the Echo lacks.  Number 2 size. Because of the speaker the size make's it hard to place. The dot is slim and easily put on a desk or can be hung on a wall. The echo however must sit on a flat surface and limits the options you can place it. I still love echo but would buy the dot if I could do it again.

Review: Bought this and a Dot. This one is in the family room and the Dot is in the Master Bedroom. Really nice to have around. I have not even scratched the surface of what it can do, but it has been handy to have around. I play lots of music with it and ask it tons of questions. I like the weather reports and news briefings also. The only drawback is that you cannot talk about Alexa without her thinking you are summoning her. If you say something to a human in the room like, "Maybe I should tell Alexa to set an alarm for me so I don't forget to walk the dog" she might hear her name and try to figure out what you are asking for. It's not a huge annoyance and you kind of learn to avoid this after a while, but it can happen. Overall, the performance is very good. Voice recognition is generally accurate, even if I speak a little less than crisply. The Dot makes a great high-tech alarm clock and the speaker in it is fine for nighttime "go to sleep" music. The speaker in the larger Echo is terrific and will fill a pretty large room.

Review: UPDATE - after much back and forth with Amazon, they agreed to exchange my defective Echo.  It should not have been this difficult to convince them that the device was defective.  I received another refurbished Echo and it appears to work just fine.  I'm changing my review to 4 stars.  I love the Echo.  But I would think twice before purchasing a refurbished one.

Review: Ever since I purchased this 4 months ago, it intermittently fails to respond.  I can see my question on the Alexa app, so I know she hears me.  I can see Alexa's answer on the app, so I know she understands me.  I can see the blue light flicker and wave, as if she were talking back to me, but no sound is coming out.  I've continued to report this issue to Amazon.  "Did you try adjusting the volume?"  Seriously?  We frogged around with resets and now I'm told that the device doesn't work as well on a Wi-fi extender.  Really?  Where was that advertised?  I also own a brand new Echo and Echo Dot.  I've moved them around to see if it's the network or the placement, but neither of those experience the same issues on the same routers when placed in the same spots.  I think the answer is to never buy "Certified Refurbished" anything from Amazon again.  I will update this review if this problem resolves with a factory reset, but I really doubt that's the issue.
label: Negative

Other times, I ask simple questions about weather, time, cooking math (i.e.how many tablespoons in a 1/4 cup).  I add things to my to-do and shopping list right as they pop in my head.  All of this I can easily do from my smartphone, but I under estimated the value and convenience of the voice commands.  Plus, now when the kids do homework, Alexa can handle many of their questions.  (i.e. spelling)

Review: Excellent product and definitely deserves 5 stars.  One thing I would really like to ask Amazon though is to create Echo's that are receivers only.  Why?  Well it is very nice to just tell Alexa to turn on a certain channel without needing a remote control.  This however will not work well when the volume is loud.  Other one is when you want the full sized echo to play music in the main room when you are not in direct view.  This requires yelling which is not great as well.  If you have an echo it plays out of the small speaker on the dot. Not great as well.  Lastly, what if you tell the large Alexa to play music and she is playing it loud.  You literally have to get right in front of it to get her to stop since it cannot hear over the music.  SO A SHOUT OUT TO AMAZON.  FIX THIS ISSUE and that would be awesome.  I CAN HEAR ALEXA LOUDLY ALMOST ANYWHERE, BUT HARD FOR IT TO HEAR ME.  VOICE RECEIVERS IS AN EASY SOLUTION.

Review: When I first considered getting an Echo, I really didn't think I was going to use it all that much. I decided to grab one when it was on sale for Prime Day, and at first it seemed like just a novelty. After having it around a few weeks, I very quickly realized all the potential for this little device. I started out just having it play music, which it does a very good job with, but pretty soon I started asking it questions, creating lists, and finding all sorts of other things I can do with it. I have an Ecobee wifi thermostat, and I can control control the temperature by having Alexa adjust it just by asking. I recently purchased Philips Hue lights, and now I can control  my living room lights just by telling Alexa what lights or scene I want turned on or off. The more I use the Echo the more I like it, and it just keeps getting better.

Review: I love Alexa!  I watch less TV and now listen more to soothing music.  Nearing bedtime, I ask Alexa to play "New Age for Sleep," then right before getting into bed I ask her to play Ocean Sounds, then ask for a sleep timer.  I fall asleep listening to waves lapping.  She's the best!

I do have faith that Amazon will continue to improve the product and resolve these issues.

Review: One improvement I'd like to see would be adding a separate setting for Alexa's voice and separate for music (this will make sense if you have used Alexa). We often listen to music over dinner at a low volume, then ask Alexa a question--she answers at the same volume the music was set at. It would be great if her voice could have a separate volume control in a setting preference so she could be heard over background music that is being played low (for example, we are listening to music, then say, "Alexa, what is the temperature outside." She answers the temperature in the same volume as the music, which is too low to hear her (it?) but is a good volume to hear "dinner music" at. Maybe this can be changed in a future version or added to her many skills! Overall, we love it (her?) and plan to add dots and integrate some smart home features.
label: Positive

Review: Another feature I'd like would be ability to add a bluetooth speaker so that there could be sound at both ends of a room. I do miss my "stereo" sound, but the ease of using Alexa is changing how I access my music (is there a slogan there? ;) ). Many have said that Alexa's speaker misses the bass. I am not a soundaphile, but I do find this is true but not to the point of me wanting a dot with bluetooth--because there would be more wires and need to sync the speaker each time it is accessed which to me, is too clumsy.

Review: This is perfect if you are using it a lot for music.  But if you are primarily using it for anything else or need lots of volume, seriously look at the Echo Dot.  I have a really nice bluetooth speaker that I connect to the dot when I need additional volume.  If you are routinely using for music, using an external speaker and constantly pairing it to power it up would not be practical, so this is the unit you would want.  I would recommend this to any of my music loving friends who would use it as their primary sound source.

Review: Bought this for a present for family but when they received one from someone else I decided to keep for myself instead of sending it back.  I am so happy I did.  Thought it would be a fun electronics to have but didn't think too seriously about the practical side of having it. Now it is my go to time teller, weather announcer, music player, wake up alarm, and general question answerer.  Not sure I would want to do without it. I especially love it when I have one song on my mind that I want to hear and don't want to dig through my favorite lists to find it.  I just ask Alexa for it and within seconds I am enjoying it. Will I ever buy and hook up light switches and heat and air controls to it - doubtful; but do I truly enjoy the fun of immediate responses to questions for time, temp, info and music - you bet!

Review: Alexa is my new bestie. I can name practically any song ever written and this device will play it. The sound quality is pretty good for this audiophile girl..but of course deluxe speakers are always better. Still, this does have more than adequate sound quality and decent volume for music. I love the feature where I can ask for an artist and it will play a playlist by that artist! It is tons of fun with guests!  I think eventually it will be able to do more and more, but it is limited in some things. You do have to be very specific about how you ask your question to get a response. There is a small learning curve.  But for keeping lists, for remembering when the pet was fed, for smart home tech, news, weather, finding stores and restaurants  and simply for fun, I love this gadget! I haven't used the shopping feature (ordering products from Amazon) yet, but I'm sure I will. Being able to link it with your cell phone and to easily review the app, the history, enabling free apps, etc. is a bonus. This is the most fun toy I've had in ages. For this coolest of gadgets, I'd marry Jeff Bezos, (if I weren't already old enough to be his big sister and I'm already married)..but srsly..the Echo is the best!

Review: This product is nothing short of amazing!!!!  I thought it would be a novelty, but I'm finding I'm getting a lot of everyday use out of it.  My son loves Elvis and with my Amazon Prime selections there is plenty of Elvis songs for him to listen to.  I use it for quick weather reports and I get my flash news updates before I head out the door in the morning.  Alexa is a great help around the kitchen too.  I can have her set multiple cooking timers to alert me when things are ready to come out of the oven and she does conversions for me too. (cups in a pint, etc.)  The voice recognition is nothing short of amazing and I expected a long delay in processing voice commands, but its very short and almost like talking to a real person.  Very impressed.  It's really refreshing to have a hands free tool like the Echo to help you out.  I would highly recommend this product.

Review: I bought the Amazon Echo as a gift for my husband.  Unfortunately, it did not live up to our expectations, and we are returning it.  The main functions we wanted were to play music, help organize grocery lists, and for general inquiries such as weather, traffic, and sports.  My husband in particular wanted to be able to do the equivalent of googling for updates to various sports scores.  Unfortunately, only the music function was decent.  For groceries, you have to command Alexa individually for every item, one at a time.  And you can't delete items by voice command.  But the biggest disappointment for my husband was the inability to ask Alexa for a particular sports event score (i.e. College bowl championship).  And it doesn't recognize PGA at all - couldn't provide leaderboard info for a major PGA tournament.  Generally, we found the entire setup to be very limited when compared to Siri or Googling online.  And the traffic skill was particularly pathetic.  You can put exactly one destination in (ever) and it permanently updates you on that traffic only.  What if you and your husband work in different locations and both want to know about the commute?  And what if you want traffic information to a particular destination on a one-time basis (i.e. airport!).  Nope.  Can't do it.  I hope Amazon (or Google for that matter) can refine the technology because the voice activated tool was a very exciting prospect because neither of us like typing into the phone app when we need something.  But to be useful it has to be more flexible.

Review: The way Amazon has set up the ecosystem, third party providers such as Spotify contract with Amazon to provide plugins. Then, when you want to use the Spotify plugin, you have to give it the right keyword to invoke that plugin, followed by the correct syntax that the Spotify plugin understands.  If you do not do both of those things correctly, your request will fail.  So, for instance, if you are a Spotify customer, you could say "Alexa, play the playlist Blah from Spotify",  and that would work, but "Alexa, play the playlist Blah" would not work, nor would "Alexa play Blah from Spotify", or "Alexa play Blah".

Review: I am afraid that the poor execution of this product is a reflection of the way that Amazon has chosen to partner with third party providers as a strategy for many of their products.  This unfortunately leaves gaping holes in their solutions.  For instance, with Amazon Drive, they have no actual sync clients, but instead rely on for-profit companies to provide sync clients for them.  This strategy is seen at its most basic level with Amazon Marketplace, where the bulk of items offered for sale are not from Amazon themselves, but from third-party providers that have nothing to do with Amazon.

Hey, if I just wanted to listen to music, that's one thing... but as a personal assistant, well, I count this as a pretty major blunder. I might as well keep using other apps to fulfill these roles.
